user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_alloc_scan:
```c
static int lfs_alloc_scan(lfs_t *lfs) {
    // move lookahead buffer to the first unused block
    //
    // note we limit the lookahead buffer to at most the amount of blocks
    // checkpointed, this prevents the math in lfs_alloc from underflowing
    lfs->lookahead.start = (lfs->lookahead.start + lfs->lookahead.next) 
            % lfs->block_count;
    lfs->lookahead.next = 0;
    lfs->lookahead.size = lfs_min(
            8*lfs->cfg->lookahead_size,
            lfs->lookahead.ckpoint);

    // find mask of free blocks from tree
    memset(lfs->lookahead.buffer, 0, lfs->cfg->lookahead_size);
    int err = lfs_fs_traverse_(lfs, lfs_alloc_lookahead, lfs, true);
    if (err) {
        lfs_alloc_drop(lfs);
        return err;
    }

    return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Rule 17.8 prohibits modifying the pointer parameter itself (reassigning the parameter variable), but permits modifying the object it points to. In this function the parameter lfs is never reassigned; all assignments target members of *lfs (e.g. lfs->lookahead.start, lfs->lookahead.next, lfs->lookahead.size), which is allowed. The memset operates on lfs->lookahead.buffer (the object pointed to by a member), also allowed. Function calls (lfs_fs_traverse_, lfs_alloc_drop) pass the pointer but do not reassign the parameter within this function. Therefore there are no code fragments in this function that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 and no fragments need further investigation.
